resources.string: Utilize this section to explore groups that improve education and communication among similar professions.
Use the drop down menu to find relevant opportunities to supplement your resume.

Keep it minimalistic. Don't make your future employer strain their eyes or work to figure out your intent. 

Be concise! Long paragraphs of beautiful prose won't look attractive on paper. Try to stick to one page of text, but don't trim the meat of your resume to remove 1/4 page of text. 

Use a professional font and clean spacing.

Include one mostly if you are changing careers or are an entry level worker. Those trying to climb the ladder internally are less likely to need one. 

Focus on what you can give to a role, not what the company can do for you. Avoid "seeking" something for a "personal goal". 

If applying to many jobs, try to customize each version of your resume with a different objective to add specificity. 

Don't give generalizations! Be very specific beyond wanting "growth" or "a challenge". 

The more concise, the better. Many applicants want to shy away from saying exactly what they want so as to seem more adaptable, but only wind up seeming noncommittal. Own your goals!

Stay away from action verbs! Use the past tense to give a sense of permanence. It's all about what skills and experience you'll bring to your new job! 

Double check everything! Have several people you know read through it. 

Always check you reference, or your own, contact information! Be sure to call all the numbers on your resume to be sure they're up to date.

Be as specific as possible! Saying "worked in a restaurant" sounds a lot less helpful than "Recruited, trained, hired, and supervised workers in a restaurant setting". 

Make the employer feel the resume they receive is meant specifically for them. Do some research into what the company supports and try to tailor some points specifically to these things. For example, if your employer is big on environmental protection, place you protest attendance for animal preservation higher up! 

Don't leave off the little jobs you've taken up. The soft skills you've gained from these places are important to employers.
